visuals.title: Complex Exponentials Are Eigenfunctions of LTI Systems
visuals.description: When e^{jkω₀t} passes through an LTI system, the output is H(jkω₀)·e^{jkω₀t}. The shape is unchanged — only scaled and phase-shifted by the transfer function.

visuals.title: Periodic Signal Through an LTI System
visuals.description: Each harmonic X_k·e^{jkω₀t} is independently scaled by H(jkω₀). Output coefficients: Y_k = X_k · H(jkω₀). The system processes each frequency independently.

visuals.title: Lowpass Filter Magnitude Response |H(jω)|
visuals.description: A lowpass filter passes low frequencies (|H| ≈ 1) and attenuates high frequencies (|H| → 0). The cutoff frequency ω_c determines the transition.

visuals.title: Square Wave Through a Lowpass Filter
visuals.description: The lowpass filter removes high harmonics, rounding the sharp edges. The output looks like a smoothed version of the input.

visuals.title: Square Wave Through a Highpass Filter
visuals.description: A highpass filter removes the DC and low harmonics, keeping only the sharp transitions. The output shows spikes at the edges.

visuals.title: Input vs Output Spectra: Y_k = X_k · H(jkω₀)
visuals.description: The output spectrum is the input spectrum multiplied by the filter's frequency response at each harmonic frequency.

visuals.title: RC Lowpass Filter: Magnitude and Phase
visuals.description: H(jω) = 1/(1 + jωRC). Magnitude: 1/√(1 + (ωRC)²). Phase: −arctan(ωRC). Cutoff at ω_c = 1/RC.

visuals.title: Interactive: Pass a Signal Through a Filter
visuals.description: Choose a periodic signal and a filter type (lowpass/highpass). Watch the spectrum and time-domain output change as you adjust the cutoff frequency.

visuals.title: Eigenfunction Property: Input and Output Shape Match
visuals.description: Input: e^{j2ω₀t} (a complex exponential). Output: H(j2ω₀)·e^{j2ω₀t}. Same frequency, just scaled and phase-shifted.

visuals.title: Interactive: Output Power After Filtering
visuals.description: Apply Parseval's theorem to compute output power: P_out = Σ|Y_k|² = Σ|X_k|²·|H(jkω₀)|². Compare input and output power.
